awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: First Year Experience for Engineering, Computer Science & Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
California State University, Los Angeles seeks to meet the need for a diverse STEM workforce through the expansion and scale-up of a first-year experience (FYrE@ECST) program for undergraduate students at its College of Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology. The institution serves primarily Hispanic, first-generation, Pell-grant eligible, commuter students, and is an access institution, offering many kinds of students the opportunity to study and complete an engineering or computer science degree. The FYrE program aims to build a stronger academic foundation during the students' first year by developing the cultural and social capital necessary for students to successfully navigate their undergraduate experience.  The program uses evidence-based strategies to promote student success, including working with student cohorts, offering peer-assisted mathematics Supplementary Instruction, emphasizing hands-on labs, building classes that integrate mathematics and physics, and providing a faculty mentor throughout students? first year. 

The intellectual merit of this project is the expansion and evaluation of the FYrE model. The performance of each student cohort will be tracked during their first year, and continue for the duration of their time on campus. A multivariate, structural equation modeling (SEM) approach will be used to quantitatively respond to a set of research questions about the impact of the interventions on student attributes. The results of this work will include new knowledge about the first-year experience of low-income, Latinx-majority commuter student populations in the context of the development of their identities as engineering students. Research will be conducted on the impact of a first-year experience program that integrates engineering education best-practices such as cohorting, supplemental instruction, summer bridge experiences, a project-based Introduction to Engineering course, and integrated mathematics-physics courses on student persistence and academic performance. This knowledge will improve the ability of American universities to serve the growing population of low income Hispanic students, especially commuter students who cannot take advantage of built-in cohorting that takes place in on-campus living situations. Best practices for supporting success of first-year engineering students from underrepresented minorities have often been developed and implemented at predominantly white institutions. In a public Hispanic-serving institution in which most students are members of one or more underrepresented minority, scaling these best practices can be challenging. The FYrE@ECST program is designed for scalability and sustainability and may provide insight into successful strategies for supporting student success at similar institutions.

inst.inst_name: California State L A University Auxiliary Services Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CAL STATE LA UNIVERSITY AUXILIARY SERVICES INC

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the First-Year@ECST (FYrE) program is to strengthen engineering and computer science students preparedness during their first year, as well as to light a fire for learning and for gaining the math, science, engineering and computing skills that will enable them to complete their degrees, on time and with excellence, and thereby improve the College graduation rate. The program has been highly successful and outcomes include both improved academic performance and decreased time to degree as well as strong community building among the cohorts. The program has been institutionalized and was highly successful even throughout the pandemic.  In Fall 2021 we started our seventh cohort of FYrE students. 

The majority (65%) of students in the College of Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology (ECST) at Cal State Los Angeles are first generation commuter college students, low income, and Latinx. The project had seven goals: Expand the program to Computer Science students; Enhance the interventions for mastering physics; Study the effect of the FYrE interventions; Build a peer leaders program to support FYrE students; Develop a FYrE faculty mentor program; Develop a faculty/staff community committed to the first-year success of students; and Continuous improvement of the summer bridge (STEP) program.

Every goal was met during the funded period.  The six-year grad rate for the FYrE Fall15 cohort is higher (55%) than the university overall (52%), which is extraordinary considering that engineering majors have historically had much lower graduation rates than the university as a whole. The 5-year grad rate for the FYrE17 cohort was 42% vs 43% for the University. The 4-year graduation rate for the FYrE17 cohort (17%) is almost as high as for the University (21%), the highest 4-year grad rate the College has seen in decades. 

Assessment of the program elements throughout its six-year history has shown that the most important elements are: the summer transition program; cohorting & block scheduling during the first year; and access to designated advisors, caring faculty, and near-peer mentors. FYrE students consistently go on to take advantage of other programmatic opportunities available at the college due to the mentoring and messaging they receive during their first year.

The FYrE program team has initiated a significant culture change in the College, away from questioning whether our students are college-ready, and towards ensuring that the College is student-ready. Many additional pedagogical, advising, faculty hiring, and other activities have ensued as follow-ons to the FYrE program, made possible by institutional investments as well as additional funding from NSF, philanthropic foundations, and alumni to expand and strengthen many aspects of the pedagogical, academic and student support programs of the College.

Said one FYrE2020 student in a survey response: [My FYrE peers] helped me as I constantly felt a push and a motivation to keep going and to not allow this pandemic to deteriorate my motivation completely. A former FYrE cohort member said: COVID and remote learning was something completely new in everyone's life, but I believe the FYrE program helped me develop studying habits that were very helpful during the pandemic. 

Both the Intellectual Merit  and Broader Impact of this project is our demonstration of how an engineering college at a high-percentage HSI can build in a successful but not exorbitantly costly first-year program with longterm effects on the academic performance, confidence, and graduation success of its students. 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2021
Modified by: Emily Allen
